title: My husband is filing personal bankruptcy. can the court / trustee check my bank acct?
question: my husband is filing bk not me, i have my oen personal bank accts, does the trustee have the righ request my bank statement?
question_tags: Divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Community property in divorce,Divorce and bankruptcy,Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Fraud,Spousal debt,Marriage
answers: Since we are in California we are a community property state and so do make sure your hubby discloses his property, your joint property and any separate property (i.e. personal accounts, vehicles, etc.) or else he may run into problems for not disclosing property correctly. In short, the answer is "yes" the Trustee has the right to request bank statements and when they do (it does vary by Trustee) it is because they simply want to verify the info (i.e. balance) disclosed on the Petition. Where there is a Petition and only one filing spouse Trustees want to make sure there isn't anything fishy going on and so do prepare (but don't worry incessantly) that this may come up.

It depends. If the trustee has reason to suspect fraud, the trustee can ask for your statements. If your husband does not provide them, he can file a Motion to Deny Discharge. I have never had this happen. Between the paystubs and tax returns that the trustee receives and the questions asked, the trustee can get that information already. Disclosure is critical.
